data.title: Navigation in JS doesn't work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.12

I wonder how to navigate in Javascript code in VS code. 
To figure out the behavior, I made this little project : 

- js
- js/index.js
- js/foo.js

index.js

    var person = {}
    
    person.name = "azeaze"
    
    person.sayHello = function() {
      console.log("Hi! My name is ", this.name)
    }

foo.js

    console.log('In foo module')
    
    person.sayHello()

jsconfig.json

    {
        "compilerOptions": {
            "target": "ES5"
        },
        "exclude": [
            "node_modules"
        ],
        "include": [
            "js/*"
        ]
    }

What I need is to navigate, from the foo.js file when I click on person.sayHello. I tried Cmd-click or F12 but VS Code replies "No definition found for sayHello". Why VS code can't?

May be the use of module is required? If so, is there a way to handle legacy code (pure ES5 code) who don't provide it? And what the purpose of "include" in jsconfig.json, if the IDE only need to follow the require? 

Edit : 
I tried to follow this answer https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28559881/debugging-navigating-js-code-in-visual-studio, that is to say add to foo.js : 

    /// <reference path="../Path/To/The/Referenced/index.js" />

But F12 navigation still doesn't work.

data.title: Tab Bar behaves inconsistently on macOS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Turn View > Show Tab Bar on
2. Open a new window: File > New Window

When in "Full Screen" mode, this adds a tab to window, and that tab stays when leaving full screen mode. When not in Full Screen mode, the steps open a new window instead of a new tab, only one of the windows is accessible when going to Full Screen Mode.

Proposed improvement: opening a new window always add a tab to the front window when Tab Bar is on.

data.title: Use V8 snapshots for the amd-loader
data.body: To improve startup performance we should use v8-snapshots. That helps with code-loading but also with initialising (static) state. There are some challenges and this issue is about identifying and assessing them.

data.title: Add Kivy language support
data.body:
**Kivy is an open source framework for graphical user interface creation with Python language**
It is a very promising framework, it is multiplatform and supports multi touch devices
Kivy Simplifies the definition of UI through simple syntax called kivy lang or kv
example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18488957/27024009-4e0efe12-4f55-11e7-844e-0b7fa808162b.png)
Please add the support of this language to the awesome VS code!
More details [here](https://kivy.org/docs/api-kivy.lang.html) about the kivy syntax.
Thanks.

data.title: Bug with tasks in realease 1.13
data.body:
Hello there,
   after the upgrade from 1.12 to 1.13 my tasks cannot run anymore.

Snippet:
```
"tasks": [
        // build
        {
            "taskName": "build BOARD_N1",
            "command": "bash",
            "args": [
                "build.sh",
                "build",
                "_BOARD_N1_"
            ],
            "problemMatcher": {
                "owner": "cpp",
                "fileLocation": ["relative", "${workspaceRoot}"],
                "pattern": {
                    "regexp": "^(.*):(\\d+):(\\d+):\\s+(warning|error):\\s+(.*)$",
                    "file": 1,
                    "line": 2,
                    "column": 3,
                    "severity": 4,
                    "message": 5
                }
            }
        },
        ...
]

```

The error is:
bash: : No such file or directory

Partial workaround is to add:
"runner": "terminal"
but this is working only for some of my tasks. If needed I can share the script to build/clean and deploy (but it worked in previous release 1.12).

data.title: Misleading error message for incorrect Explorer view manifest
data.body:
I misread the documentation for the new custom explorers feature and gave my explorer a 'node' attribute instead of 'name'. When I tested the extension, the error message was "property `label` is mandatory and must be of type `string`".  This was confusing as the only 'label' property I could think of was the one on `vscode.TreeItem`!

---

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a new VS Code extension.

2. Add the following to `package.json` under the `contributes` section:

```
    "views": {
      "explorer": [
        {
          "id": "foo",
          "node": "Foo"  // <- my mistake - should have been 'name'
        }
      ]
    }
```

3. Implement the necessary tree provider and activation event (they don't need to do anything).

4. Launch the extension in the debugger.

Expected: An error along the lines of "Contributed view 'foo' must have a 'name' property of type 'string'" (specifically identifying the 'name' property).

Actual: An error reading "property `label` is mandatory and must be of type `string`" - misidentifying the property, and not pointing at the specific culprit.

---

- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16199
- Extensions:

|---|---|---|

data.title: VSIX extension without a package.json silently fails to install

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Linux Mint

### Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Take and **.vsix** extension file
2.  Open in a archive/zip editor
3.  Delete **extension/package.json**
4.  Save the archive (vsix)
5.  Try to import the modified vsix into VS Code

Note: It is more practical that this occurs with a malformed newly created extension, but these steps are easier because they don't require `vsce`.

### Actual outcome:

No apparent error or action on VS Code's part.  The extension is not installed.

### Expected outcome:

Either the extension is installed or an error is displayed.

<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home

Steps to Reproduce:
I'm not sure... this happened after weeks of word Wrap working fine. This is reproducible with all extensions on and off. It persists between uninstall and reinstall as well. 

1. "editor.wordWrap": on,
2. Turning it off and using alt-Z and the menu all have the same result: no word wrap.

data.title: Minimap disappears when Ctrl+Click is triggered on a SCSS variable
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 Xenial Xerus
- Commit hash: 376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a two `.scss` files (eg. `main.scss` and `_part.scss`)
2. In `_part.scss` make a new variable (eg: `$color`: "blue");
3. In `main.scss` make a call to the variable, like `.color { background: $color; }`
4. Click on `$color` while holding down `ctrl` in `main.scss`. This opens the definition box for `$color`. But when it is closed (or clicking anywhere), the minimap on the right disappears

To show the minimap again, restart VS Code

data.title: Login-AzureRMAccount interactive window pops-up in background
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Win 10
- Azure Powershell December 2016

While running at **Login-AzureRMAccount** cmdlet it is launching pop-up login window at the very background, so all windows should be minimized in order to get access to it. Sometimes when you require to do that frequently, that could be painfull.
Opposite to it Powershell ISE always pops-up at the foreground.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run Login-AzureRMAccount with no params, from integrated console, powershell console, or using line code runner (F8)

data.title: Powershell cannot run scripts from the get go like it used to...
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.3.1|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open up terminal
2. Try to run .ps1 script
3. Fail miserably

Cool update, now you can't run .ps1 scripts from the get go, like you used to, and setting up policy by adding -ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted flag to terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows doesn't work too (I can't even see the error, cause it closes instantly).

That's what I've been really missing from VS Code - unnecessary setup that doesn't work anyway. Why break a perfectly functioning feature?
